thread.title: Experts predict historically bad crawfish harvest; higher prices already seen at restaurants
thread.title_full: Experts predict historically bad crawfish harvest; higher prices already seen at restaurants

author: Jordan Gartner
title: Experts predict historically bad crawfish harvest; higher prices already seen at restaurants
text:
NEW ORLEANS ( WVUE /Gray News) - Louisiana’s crawfish harvest is expected to hit a historic low in 2024.
Crawfish specialists in Louisiana are attributing the conditions to adverse weather conditions, including drought.
“It’s going to be the worst season ever,” Louisiana State University AgCenter crawfish specialist Mark Shirley told the Louisiana Radio Network . “The population is just not there.”
Louisiana Agriculture and Forestry Commissioner Mike Strain added, “We’ve lost a lot of our crawfish. They simply did not survive the drought.”
To cultivate the crustaceans, farmers traditionally cultivate a rice crop in shallow water, providing a habitat for crawfish to burrow underground.
Under optimal conditions, females can hatch between 400-900 eggs each.
But last year’s drought prevented some farmers from flooding their fields, and recent extreme weather has adversely affected the crawfish crops during crucial growth periods.
“They [fishermen] may fish all day but instead of catching 30 or 40 sacks they catch five or six,” Strain said.
Experts say the scarcity of the harvest is also driving prices up.
At Cajun Seafood restaurants in New Orleans, crawfish are selling for as much as $16.99 a pound , while this time last year they were selling for about $5 a pound.
“I am hoping that we have a short and condensed season and that we have enough crawfish for Easter because it’s just not Easter without crawfish,” he said.
Louisiana is the largest harvester of crawfish in the nation.
